newsitem.title: USA: Laser Storm sees Q4 loss of $2.5 million.
newsitem.headline: Laser Storm sees Q4 loss of $2.5 million.

text.p: Laser Storm Inc Friday said it expects to report a loss of about $2.5 million for the fourth quarter on revenues of about $773,000.

"This large loss was the result of a significant drop-off in system sales from the previous quarter, as well as high development and marketing expenses attributable to the creation of Laser Storm's new X-Men laser tag game," the company said.
No First Call consensus estimate was available for the company's fourth quarter earnings.

Laser Storm said it completed its restructuring, begun December 6. Its corporate headquarters staff has been reduced by 30 employees. Chief Executive Bob Cooney said, "The salary reductions alone will reduce the company's overhead by $1.5 million in 1997. Additional cost reductions in marketing, development, travel and other areas should reduce the company's expenses by an additional $1.0 million in 1997 over 1996."

The company said additional write-offs resulted from the termination of employees and officers under employment pacts. It estimates its loss for all of 1996 will be about $2.6 million on revenues of about $5.9 million.

While the company incurred a loss in January, it was able to take additional cost-savings measures in early February. These measures, along with increased sales, allowed it to show a positive EBITDA in February.

Cooney added, "We are excited about our financial performance in February, and March prospects look encouraging. The sales cycle for equipment sales, however, tends to be quite lengthy. This makes short-term sales predictability extremely difficult. This underscores the need to build our recurring revenue streams by opening additional company-owned stores."
Laser Storm is pursuing various financing alternatives to continue the rollout of its company-owned stores and to meet its working capital requirements.

Laser Storm, an operator of themed laser tag entertainment centers, also said the exercise price of the warrants issued as a part of the units in its public offering in April 1996 would almost certainly be reduced to $1.00 per share. The exercise price is adjustable based on the company's financial performance for the 12-month period ending March 31, 1997.
